results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 1-3.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: A series of videos examining the changing nature of work in contemporary Australian society and primarily aimed at audiences from non-English speaking backgrounds. In episode 1, “Improving your skills”, Rosa undertakes English classes to learn to read and write, and in the long term, to be able to take further courses to improve her skills. In “Finding a career” Trahn is encouraged by a work friend to learn English and find work similar to the job he left in Vietnam. In “Looking to the future” workers on a building site discuss the long-term importance of superannuation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV

results.title: England in the Middle Ages
results.creator_credit: David Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Education Foundation for Visual Arts
results.brief_description: An overview of four hundred years of British history. Deals with the impact of the Norman Invasion; the Doomsday Book; the structure of medieval society; the importance of religion, castles, cathedrals and abbeys; the development of towns and trade; the Magna Carta; the Crusades; the beginnings of parliament; the Black Death; the decline of the fuedal system; the Peasant Revolt; the rise of the university and the Hundred Years War.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Boulton, Boulton-Hawker Films and Education Foundation for Visual Arts

results.title: En Toute Innocence = No Harm Intended
results.brief_description:
Paul Duchene runs an architecture practice with his son Thomas and Thomas’ wife, Catherine. One day, Paul finds Catherine in the arms of one of his assistants. Seething with rage, he drives off in his car and has an accident that leaves him crippled and mute. Failing a reconciliation, his daughter-in-law plans his murder.

Credits: Producer, Louis Duchesne ; director, Alain Jessua ; writers, Luc Beraud, Alain Jessua, Dominique Roulet ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Michel Portal.
Cast: Michel Serrault, Nathalie Baye, Francois Dunoyer, Suzanne Flon, Philippe Caroit.

results.title: Enginemen
results.creator_credit: Michael Grigsby, British Film Institute and Unit Five Seven
results.brief_description: An outstanding documentary offering an impression of engine at locomotive sheds on the outskirts of Manchester, filmed during the early hours of a wintry morning. There is very little commentary other than the men themselves commenting on the changes being brought about in their lives by extensive dieselisation.

results.title: Energy Victoria
results.brief_description: A brief promotional overview of the corporate activities of Energy Victoria. Services highlighted are those which assist clients to conserve energy and allow for the development of renewable resources. There is no dialogue but the images are accompanied by a soundtrack.

results.title: Emus: curious companions. Echidna: the survivor
results.creator_credit: Mike Piper, Richard Campbell, Jim Roberts, ABC-TV (Australia), National Geographic Society and Piper Films
results.brief_description: Two separate episodes examine two of Austalia’s best-loved animals, the emu and the echidna. ‘Emu - curious companions’ follows the work of researcher Cate Coddington. Her study of one of Australia’s most recognisable birds involved following a group of emus through a cold Canberra winter. In the process she discovered startling information about their breeding habits and social systems. ‘Echidna - the survivor’, filmed on Kangaroo Island, South Australia, presents one of Australia’s least-known mammals, through the work of researchers Dr. Peggy Rismiller and Mike McKelvey.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Piper, Richard Campbell, Jim Roberts, ABC-TV (Australia), National Geographic Society and Piper Films

results.title: Energetics of life
results.creator_credit: Mallory Pearce, Daniel E. Atkinson, E.A. Carlson and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description: Treats the types and functions of energy in living things - kinetic and potential energy; thermodynamics; free energy and chemical energy. Described in detail are the structure and function of the ATP molecule; photosynthesis; the metabolism of glucose. Emphasizes the ability of the ATP molecule to harness solar energy and use it

results.title: Energy management for the future
results.creator_credit: Michael Melnyk, Patrick Loubert, Melvana Communications Group and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Our society is rapidly depleting its energy bank. This film creates awareness of the seriousness of the situation, what measures the federal government has taken, and how each one of us can help slow down the rapid consumption of non-renewable resources.

results.title: Enemy alien
results.creator_credit: Jeanette Lerman, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about a people who dared to ask: “What are they going to do with us?” The Japanese-Canadians fought long and hard to be accepted as Canadians. It is important that the long story of frustration and injustice, mistrust and hate, and eventual triumph should be remembered. This film tells that story. (Awards: New York; Birmingham.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeanette Lerman, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Endoscopic Vanitas (No Veins Version)
results.credit_line:
Shaun Gladwell
plastic skull, endoscopic cameras, mechanised mount, transformer, fog machine and projection
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, plastic skull, endoscopic cameras, mechanised mount, transformer, fog machine and projection
results.brief_description:
“Endoscopic Vanitas (No Veins Version)” is a reworking of a past work, originally exhibited in 2009 at the Venice Biennale, commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences” in 2011.

In the centre of the room a single human skull hangs suspended by a metal frame. An endoscopic camera moves inside the skull, a second explores its exterior. The images captured by the two cameras are projected onto separate screens, the first a mist screen that sits at the entrance to the room creating a permeable barrier to the cavernous space behind, the second a simple LCD screen inside the room. These images appear abstract, suggestive, lunar. Gladwell is playing with the time-honoured trope of the momento mori, as well as with Plato’s ‘allegory of the cave’.
